climbs.name: Toast
climbs.fa: Zack Mintz, Kim Pfabe, Jim Thornburg

content.description:
This route offers varied climbing and is well-protected. If there's already a crowd climbing Amazing Face, don't hesitate to give Toast a try - it makes another excellent option for the 5.10 leader.

Slopers make up a majority of the holds, along with several delightful pockets. Mantles and high-steps are occasionally required for upward progress. Some of the sequences may seem confounding until you work out the right beta.
content.protection: Eight glue-in bolts (2020) to clip as you climb. Three glue-ins equipped with chains and mussies for lowering.
content.location: The right-side face of the Lower Tier hosts three climbs (one crack and two sport). Toast starts furthest to the right, though ultimately all three routes join and share lower-offs.

content.description:
Relaxed crimping gets you past the first three bolts and into the crack. Take the crack up a little ways. Then, traverse right onto the thin face and pull some hard crimps to progress. The angle lessens and the climbs eases, but not too much, at the top.

Good, occasionally creative, footwork is helpful. Opportunities for slab trickery abound.
content.protection:
Ten bolts (2020) to a two-bolt anchor with chains + mussy hooks.

For top rope, the anchors may be accessed by a short rap off a tree. Watch out for poison oak up there.
content.location: Start left of Diagonal Crack for three bolts, then join the crack briefly before finishing up and to the right.

content.description:
The direct start to Ozone involves some interesting mantle moves up a sandstone face. This route is located on the far left side of the lower tier.

The serious rating is so because there is no place for pro until you get up to the cracked roof, which is about 20 feet off the ground, and the crux is getting to the roof.

Once the hands run out, traverse up and left to the main crack of ozone, and then over the roof and finish off on ozone.
content.protection: friends to 3". Bring a long sling (30'+) for a toprope, which can be set up off a tree directly above the route.

content.description:
Start on the chimney for 3 bolts before breaking right. Crux seemed to be towards the top with some layback moves.

Bolts seemed oddly placed throughout and would result in unnecessarily awkward but mostly safe falls.
content.protection: 10 glue-in bolts to a Mussy hook anchor. Many reachy clips, so prehanging the draws is nice (especially #3 if you're short).
content.location:
Bolted line between the Chimney and Amazing Face.

Anchor can be accessed for TR with a short diagonal rap from Amazing Face's old upper anchor.

climbs.name: Miwok
climbs.fa: Rances Rodriguez, Francisco Herrera, Jim Thornburg, Perry Doig

content.description:
Another excellent 5.11 face climb on the Lower Tier. This route stands out as being more balancy than the others.

Two different teams had two different visions for the start of the route. One bolted the easier chimney start, the other did the direct start. The chimney start keeps the climb on the easier end of 5.11. The direct start, however, bumps the climb up to somewhere around the .11+/.12- range.
content.protection:
Ten glue-in bolts (2021). Two-bolt anchor with chains + mussies at the top.

For top rope, the anchors may be accessed by a short rap off a tree. A few directionals will be appreciated. Watch out for poison oak up there.
content.location: This is the first route to the left of the obvious chimney that divides the Lower Tier.

content.description:
Broken holds at the bottom have upped the grade over the years. Climbing through the first three bolts involves desperate crimping and nothing for feet, and seems at least as hard as any of the sequences on Dinosaur.

Gaining the fourth bolt involves running it out on sandy rock. If the climber blows it at the end, the belayer will have to be attentive to prevent a ground fall.

After that, the rest of the climb is a delight, involving interesting movement on slopey dishes and surprisingly crisp crimps.
content.protection:
Seven glue-in bolts (6"; 2013). Stick clip highly recommended.

The anchors (in Oct. '21) are manky old chains that look like they belong in a BDSM fantasy. It's easy to traverse left to the anchors of Bolt Route, using a good rail for hands, for a more confidence-inspiring lower.
content.location: To the right of Bolt Route. Currently the rightmost line on this sector of the Lower Tier.

content.description:
In my opinion the best route of Diablo. Climbs a series of very small crimps immediately right of "Diagonal Crack". Offers a wide variety of face moves including side-pulls, mantles, and high-stepping on tiny holds. Arrange long anchor slings if you want to avoid the final runout mantle on loose rock. Reminiscent of J.Tree climbing.

The first bolt is a solid 15' high, so consider pre-clipping.
content.protection:
Eight bolts (6" glue-ins; 2021); or nine if you clip the last bolt on Miwok at the top. Mussy hooks to lower off.

For top rope, the anchors may be accessed by a short rap off a tree. Watch out for poison oak up there.

content.description:
The only goofy looking crack on the whole face. Climb the diagnoal crack, which is unlike many cracks in that it is comprised of little subpockets within the crack, so you can actally pinch things inside of the crack in addition to jamming.

On a top rope, you will take a substantial swing if you fall on the top portion of this climb, but there's nothing to hit in the swing, except for other climbers.
content.protection: Most people top-rope this route, but if you're insane, cams and nuts up to 3". If you do lead it, there are three glue-in bolts that will take you to the anchors for Stegosaurus, which you can lower off from.

content.description: The route is a 5.7 crack that ranges from fingers to fists for most of it. The crux is the bottom third. Once you get to the tree it eases up quite a bit. Some good face holds to the right and the left.
content.protection:
Cams from .5-4 will protect this sandy mother on lead. The tree halfway up can be slung.

There are two options for lowering: (1) Use a single, old, mechanical bolt + quick link at the top of the crack. Looks pretty sketchy - not recommended. (2) Climb up the headwall above the crack (two bolts) and lower off the mussies up there (shared with the bolted line to the right). Be aware that the headwall is moderate 5.10, not 5.7.

It is easy to set up a top-rope after leading the route to the right of the crack.
content.location: The route is an unmistakable crack in the corner just as you round the west face of the Lower Tier. There is a small tree about a third of the way up.

content.description:
Climb the large chimney in the middle of the rock. Nudge, squirm, jam, and any other moves can and will be used to get you up this chimney. All the moves are rests, so running out of gas is not an issue.

Crux is getting through the bulge towards the top of the route.

There's also an interesting cave in the middle of the route that heads beck a ways into the rock.
content.protection:
Huge friends (up to 5") for a trad lead.

Two bolts allow for top-roping. It would be a good idea, though, to back them up with the nearby tree (around 20' of webbing should do the trick).

climbs.name: Bolt Route
climbs.fa: Whoever you are, I'll buy you a beer

content.description: On the east face of the Lower Tier, immediately right of the route with two giant holes at the bottom (Amazing Face). Very pumpy and unrelenting (5.11+) for the first several bolts then eases up to mid 5.10 for the rest. There are cruxy moves at the top and bottom of the climb, and knowing which holds to use is key. Trust your feet and be patient.
content.protection: There are 13 bolts (6" glue-ins; 2013), with chain anchors up top. No mussy hooks, so bring your PAS and thread the chains to clean.

content.description: The crux is at the middle when you have tiny slopers and tiny foot holds. There are some good shallow pockets and crimpy side pulls at the top. Not a lot of strength needed. Good foot work and trust in your smearing technique goes a long way.
content.protection: Nine glue-in bolts (2020) to clip as you go up. Three glue-ins all equipped with chains and mussy hooks for lowering.
content.location: On the west face of the Lower Tier, the start is about 4-5 feet to the right of a very prominent 5.7 crack (Diablo Jam). It is the left of the two bolted lines (the line on the right is Toast).

climbs.name: The Arch (a.k.a. Ozone)
climbs.fa: Claude Fiddler and Patrick Sawyer, ca. 1974

content.description: Lieback the left side of the arch until you're almost to the top, then reach left to the thin crack above the roof, traverse this up and right until it joins a wider, vertical crack.  Follow this one to the top. Ozone is a really unique climb that requires a lot of upper body strength.
content.protection:
Two bolts at the top to set up a top rope. There is also a tree above the route that can be used as an anchor with long slings.

Approach it by hiking up the steep trail left of the lower tier. Go right towards the face at the first turn.
content.location: The furthest left climb on the lower tier.

content.description:
By far the most-wanted route in the area, some weekends there are parties lined up for it all day. Start by climbing to, and using, the big holes. The moves here can be equal parts powerful and awkward. After exiting the second hole, delicately balance your way up the amazingest goshdarn face. Towards the top, the holds become slope-y, and thoughtful beta is required.

P.S. The belayer gets two points for dropping a falling climber into either of the man-eating holes at the bottom of the route.
content.protection:
Ten glue-in bolts (2020) lead to a bolted anchor (three chains, each with its own mussy hook).

Another anchor exists on top to allow climbers to safely rappel to the lower chains for top roping. Please use the lower chain anchor for top-roping and lowering to stop the rope scarring and the grooves left behind in the soft rock.

Please use your own gear for top roping off the chains to minimize wear on the expensive fixed gear, and NEVER thread a rope through the eye of a glue in bolt for any reason but an unavoidable emergency.
content.location: Immediately identifiable by the two big holes that you climb into at the start.
